Emerging: Try naming your feelings when they happen - happy, sad, mad, or worried
Ask a trusted adult to help you understand why you feel a certain way
Start noticing: What makes you happy? What makes you upset?
Developing: Keep a feelings journal - write down how you feel each day and why
Name specific emotions like frustrated, anxious, or excited (not just happy/sad)
Think about one thing you're good at and one thing you want to improve
Proficient: Notice how your emotions affect your actions - do you work better when calm?
Describe your learning style: Do you learn best by doing, seeing, or hearing?
Recognize patterns: What situations make you feel your best?
Advanced: Reflect on WHY you want to achieve certain goals - what motivates you?
Use your self-knowledge to pick challenges that help you grow
Practice metacognition: Think about how you think and learn

Emerging: Take 3 deep breaths when you feel upset before reacting
Ask an adult to remind you to stay focused on your work
Try again even when something feels hard - don't give up right away
Developing: Use simple calming strategies: count to 10, take a walk, or squeeze a stress ball
Break big tasks into smaller pieces and tackle one piece at a time
Set a timer to help you stay on task for short periods (like 10 minutes)
Proficient: Create your own toolbox of strategies: deep breathing, exercise, music, or journaling
Set short-term goals (like finishing homework before dinner) and track your progress
Keep trying even when tasks are challenging - persistence pays off!
Advanced: Notice when you're stressed and choose the best coping strategy for that situation
Set long-term goals (like improving a grade over the semester) and check progress weekly
Adapt your strategies based on what works - be your own scientist!

Emerging: Look at people's faces to see if they seem happy, sad, or angry
Ask yourself: How would I feel if someone did that to me?
Learn basic classroom rules: raise your hand, take turns, be kind
Developing: Pay attention to body language - crossed arms might mean someone is upset
Try to see things from another person's point of view
Notice when someone needs help and offer to assist them
Proficient: Read subtle cues like tone of voice or facial expressions to understand feelings
Show empathy by saying things like 'That must be hard for you'
Respect that people from different backgrounds may have different customs
Advanced: Actively seek to understand perspectives very different from your own
Stand up for others when you see unfairness or exclusion
Use your understanding of others to bring people together and build community

Emerging: Practice sharing and taking turns with others
Wait for your turn to speak instead of interrupting
Use your words to ask for help: 'Can you please help me with this?'
Developing: Participate in group work by doing your part
Tell others what you need: 'I feel frustrated when...'
When there's a small conflict, ask an adult to help you work it out
Proficient: Communicate clearly and respectfully - say what you mean kindly
Listen actively: look at the speaker, nod, and ask questions
Compromise with peers - find solutions that work for everyone
Advanced: Build strong friendships across different groups - include everyone
Help your friends communicate better when they have conflicts
Lead team projects by making sure everyone's voice is heard

Emerging: Stop and think before you act - count to 5 first
Ask yourself: Is this safe? Is this kind?
Follow safety rules even when no one is watching
Developing: List the good and bad things that might happen before making a choice
Make safe choices in familiar situations (like at school or home)
Think about how your choice affects others, not just yourself
Proficient: Use a decision-making process: What are my options? What could happen? What's best?
Consider ethics: Is this fair? Is it honest? Does it help or hurt others?
Make choices that keep you and others safe and happy
Advanced: Think about long-term consequences - how will this affect me next week? Next year?
Consider unintended outcomes - what else might happen that I didn't plan for?
Make decisions that benefit your whole community, not just yourself

Emerging: Ask adults to repeat directions if you forget
Focus on one step at a time when following instructions
Write things down or draw pictures to help you remember
Developing: Follow 3-4 step directions by repeating them to yourself
Ask yourself: What am I supposed to be doing right now?
Connect new information to things you already know
Proficient: Follow complex, multi-step instructions without needing reminders
Hold information in your mind while using it (like solving a long math problem)
Take good notes to help you remember and use information later
Advanced: Combine information from different sources to form new ideas
Manage multiple tasks in your head at once without getting confused
Create systems (like mnemonics or diagrams) to remember complex information

Emerging: Notice when you're distracted and try to refocus on your work
Practice pausing for 3 seconds before blurting out answers
Ask for help if you can't stop a behavior that's not working
Developing: Use tools to block distractions: put away your phone, close extra tabs
Think before speaking - mentally count to 3 before answering
Start and stop tasks when asked (even if you're not finished yet)
Proficient: Work effectively even when there's moderate noise or activity around you
Always think before speaking or acting - make it a habit
Delay fun activities to finish necessary work first
Advanced: Identify potential distractions ahead of time and remove them before starting work
Maintain laser focus during long, complex tasks (like a multi-hour project)
Stay calm and focused even in stressful or emotional situations

Emerging: Try to stay calm when plans change - it's okay if things are different!
If one way doesn't work, try asking for help to find another way
Give yourself time to adjust when transitioning between activities
Developing: When Plan A fails, brainstorm a Plan B with help
Accept small changes to routines without getting too upset
Try seeing a problem from another person's perspective
Proficient: Easily switch between different tasks or subjects
Generate multiple solutions to a problem and choose the best one
Adapt your strategy when you get new information that changes things
Advanced: Embrace challenges and changes as opportunities to grow
Come up with creative, innovative solutions by thinking in new ways
Hold multiple conflicting ideas in your mind and evaluate them fairly

Emerging: Ask someone to help you make a plan before starting big tasks
Guess how long something will take (you'll get better with practice!)
Work on the most important thing first
Developing: Create simple step-by-step plans when given guidance
Prioritize your top 2-3 tasks with adult help
Break large projects into smaller chunks (one page at a time!)
Proficient: Make detailed plans for long-term projects on your own
Estimate time accurately: 'This will take about 30 minutes'
Prioritize based on what's urgent AND important
Advanced: Create backup plans in case your first plan doesn't work out
Manage multiple big projects at the same time without getting overwhelmed
Allocate your time, energy, and materials for maximum efficiency

Emerging: Try to keep your desk and backpack somewhat tidy with daily reminders
Use a folder or binder to keep papers from getting lost
Clean out your backpack once a week - toss old papers and trash
Developing: Keep materials organized with daily adult check-ins
Use a planner (even if you forget to check it sometimes)
Have a specific place for everything - keys, homework, pencils
Proficient: Maintain organized physical and digital workspaces independently
Use a planner or digital tool consistently to track assignments
Take clear, structured notes that help you study later
Advanced: Develop your own personalized organization system that works for YOU
Help friends or classmates organize their materials or study space
Create long-term filing systems so you can find information months later

Emerging: Start working after 1-2 reminders from an adult
Ask for help figuring out the first step of a task
Try to begin even when the task seems hard or boring
Developing: Start tasks with just one reminder
Begin work if someone tells you the very first thing to do
Find one thing that interests you about the task to help you start
Proficient: Start tasks quickly even if they're challenging or uninteresting
Break down large tasks and identify your own first step
Use the '2-minute rule': if it takes less than 2 minutes, do it now!
Advanced: Jump into complex, self-directed projects with enthusiasm
Motivate yourself AND others to get started on work
Generate multiple possible starting points and pick the best one

Emerging: Ask questions when something doesn't make sense to you
Learn to tell the difference between a fact and someone's opinion
Don't believe everything you hear - it's okay to wonder if it's true
Developing: Separate facts from opinions by asking 'How do we know this is true?'
Question information when reminded to think critically
Identify simple bias: 'Does this person have a reason to say this?'
Proficient: Analyze information from multiple sources before forming an opinion
Check the credibility of sources: Who wrote this? Are they an expert?
Build arguments supported by solid evidence, not just feelings
Advanced: Combine complex, even contradictory information to form original insights
Develop and test your own hypotheses like a scientist
Identify and challenge hidden assumptions in arguments and problems

Emerging: Try to express your ideas clearly, even if they're not perfect
Speak up in small groups, even if it feels scary at first
Write in complete sentences and check your work for big errors
Developing: Share basic information clearly so others understand you
Participate in discussions when the teacher calls on you
Write organized paragraphs with a beginning, middle, and end
Proficient: Explain complex ideas clearly in both speaking and writing
Adjust how you communicate based on your audience (formal vs. casual)
Use digital tools (slides, videos, documents) to share your ideas effectively
Advanced: Use sophisticated vocabulary and persuasive techniques to inspire others
Communicate effectively across cultural and language differences
Create compelling presentations that influence how people think

Emerging: Work with your group even if it's hard - don't withdraw or take over
Try to share responsibilities and take turns doing tasks
Focus on the whole project, not just your own part
Developing: Work well in groups when everyone has clear roles and supervision
Share your ideas when asked and listen to others' ideas too
Compromise on small things when your group can't agree
Proficient: Work effectively and respectfully with all kinds of team members
Really listen to others' ideas and build on them
Share responsibility equally and help your group succeed together
Advanced: Lead collaborative projects by creating an inclusive environment
Help resolve group conflicts in constructive, fair ways
Elevate the quality of group work through shared vision and effort

Emerging: Try new approaches instead of always copying what others do
Brainstorm ideas even if they seem silly at first
Be willing to try something different when encouraged
Developing: Generate a few original ideas when given a specific prompt
Try a new approach if someone guides you through it
Build on other people's ideas to make them your own
Proficient: Come up with original ideas and solutions on your own
Refine and improve your ideas based on feedback
Apply creative thinking to solve real problems in new ways
Advanced: Consistently produce truly novel and valuable solutions
Connect seemingly unrelated concepts to create innovations
Inspire others to think creatively and take creative risks

Emerging: Learn to use technology for schoolwork, not just games and videos
Practice organizing files into folders so you can find them later
Create a strong password and keep it private
Developing: Use required software and apps for school assignments
Understand basic online safety: don't share personal information
Ask for help evaluating if a website is trustworthy
Proficient: Use a variety of digital tools for research, organization, and creation
Practice safe, ethical, and responsible online behavior
Evaluate the reliability of online sources before trusting them
Advanced: Critically analyze digital information and media for bias and accuracy
Troubleshoot technical problems on your own or with minimal help
Use advanced tools to create and manage complex digital projects

Emerging: Learn about countries and cultures beyond your own community
Show curiosity when you encounter people with different backgrounds
Recognize that not everyone lives the same way you do
Developing: Name a few global issues like climate change or poverty
Ask questions and show interest when learning about diverse cultures
Understand that people around the world are both similar and different
Proficient: Explain how global issues like climate or economics are interconnected
Appreciate and respect diverse cultures and perspectives
Recognize how local decisions can have global impacts
Advanced: Research and advocate for solutions to global challenges
Apply cross-cultural understanding in real interactions with others
See local issues through a global lens and vice versa
